data.title: BostonPL_The Irish War of Independence, 1919-1921 - Boston Public Library
data.meta_description: BostonPL_The Irish War of Independence, 1919-1921 by BostonPL_EileenS - a community-created list : The Irish War of Independence was fought against the forces of British rule in Ireland from 1919-1921. The war ended on December 6, 1921 with the signing of the Anglo-Irish Treaty which granted a measure of self-rule to 26 of Ireland's 32 counties. To learn more about the conflict, check out this list of resources.
data.text:
Renowned Irish historian Diarmaid Ferriter presents a new look at the Irish revolutionary period from 1913-1923, drawing from newly available historical s...Show more Renowned Irish historian Diarmaid Ferriter presents a new look at the Irish revolutionary period from 1913-1923, drawing from newly available historical sources as well as the testimonies of the people who lived and fought through this extraordinary period. Show less

Traces the life of the charismatic Collins, one of the key figures in the Irish War of Independence. Collins focused on intelligence and counter-intelligence, and was instrumental in destroying the British Secret Service network in Dublin. Traces the life of the charismatic Collins, one of the key figures in the Irish War of Independence. Collins focused on intelligence and counter-intelligence, and was instrumental in destroying the British Secret Service network in Dublin. Show less

In-library use only at this time in some locations

Breen was present at the Soloheadbeg Ambush on January 21, 1919, where the first shots were fired in the Irish War of Independence. "My Fight for Irish Freedom" is his bestselling account of his role in that war. Breen was present at the Soloheadbeg Ambush on January 21, 1919, where the first shots were fired in the Irish War of Independence. "My Fight for Irish Freedom" is his bestselling account of his role in that war. Show less

All copies in use Availability details

A comprehensive account of the revolutionary period, with over 400 color illustrations, maps and photographs. A comprehensive account of the revolutionary period, with over 400 color illustrations, maps and photographs. Show less

The British government sent over additional forces - the Black and Tans and the Auxiliaries -to assist the Royal Irish Constabulary in their fight against the Irish Republican Army. Leeson looks at the role those forces played. The British government sent over additional forces - the Black and Tans and the Auxiliaries -to assist the Royal Irish Constabulary in their fight against the Irish Republican Army. Leeson looks at the role those forces played. Show less

Examining the years 1917-22, this biography traces the parallel careers and political lives of Michael Collins and Eamon de Valera, two leaders of the Iri...Show more Examining the years 1917-22, this biography traces the parallel careers and political lives of Michael Collins and Eamon de Valera, two leaders of the Irish revolution who were very different in temperament and style. It also considers the legacy of Collins on de Valera's later political life. Show less

Like many of the Irish, O'Malley was largely indifferent to the attempts to establish an independent Ireland--until the Easter Rising of 1916. As the fight progressed his feelings changed and he joined the Irish Republican Army. Like many of the Irish, O'Malley was largely indifferent to the attempts to establish an independent Ireland--until the Easter Rising of 1916. As the fight progressed his feelings changed and he joined the Irish Republican Army. Show less

All copies in use Availability details

Walsh demonstrates how this national revolution, which captured worldwide attention from India to Argentina, was itself shaped by international events, po...Show more Walsh demonstrates how this national revolution, which captured worldwide attention from India to Argentina, was itself shaped by international events, political, economic, and cultural. In the era of Russian Bolshevism and American jazz, developments in Europe and America had a profound effect on Ireland. Show less

Michael Collins, intelligence chief of the Irish Republican Army, created an elite squad whose role was to assassinate British agents and undercover polic...Show more Michael Collins, intelligence chief of the Irish Republican Army, created an elite squad whose role was to assassinate British agents and undercover police. The so-called 'Twelve Apostles.' Bestselling historian Tim Pat Coogan not only tells the story of Collins' squad, he also examines the remarkable intelligence network of which it formed a part, and which helped to bring the British government to the negotiating table. Show less

Markievicz was a key figure in Ireland's political and literary renaissance in the early years of the twentieth century. She was sentenced to death for he...Show more Markievicz was a key figure in Ireland's political and literary renaissance in the early years of the twentieth century. She was sentenced to death for her role in the 1916 Rising, but the sentence was commuted to life in prison. While still in prison, she made history as the first woman elected to the British Parliament. She refused to take her seat in Westminster and, along with the other Sinn Fein members, formed the first Dail (Irish Parliament) in Dublin where she served as Minister of Labor. Show less

Tim Pat Coogan charts the relationship between Gaelic sports and Ireland's national struggle in the period 1916-23 and explores the central role they have played in the social, cultural and political life of nationalistic Ireland. Tim Pat Coogan charts the relationship between Gaelic sports and Ireland's national struggle in the period 1916-23 and explores the central role they have played in the social, cultural and political life of nationalistic Ireland. Show less

McCoole looks at the role of women in the Irish revolutionary movement of the early twentieth century, profiling over 70 who fought for Irish independence. McCoole looks at the role of women in the Irish revolutionary movement of the early twentieth century, profiling over 70 who fought for Irish independence. Show less

Barry's account of his time as commander of the 3rd West Cork Brigade's flying column during the Irish War of Independence. Barry's account of his time as commander of the 3rd West Cork Brigade's flying column during the Irish War of Independence. Show less

In-library use only in some locations

Clarke was a founder member of Cumann na mBan (Irish women's revolutionary organization), and political activist. Both her husband and her brother were ex...Show more Clarke was a founder member of Cumann na mBan (Irish women's revolutionary organization), and political activist. Both her husband and her brother were executed by the British for their role in the 1916 Rising. Along with Countess Markievicz, she was jailed for her political activities. During the Irish War of Independence Clarke served as a Judge on the Republican Courts in Dublin. When the war was over, she remained involved in politics and became the first woman Lord Mayor of Dublin in 1939. Show less
